config.domain_knowledge:
Regarding identification of automated visualization papers:

The following keywords are used to identify the automated visualization papers:
- automatic vis
- automated vis
- visualization recommendation
- mixed initiative
- mixed-initiative
- visualization generation
- vis generation
- agent

An example vega-lite filter:
test(/automatic vis|automated vis|visualization recommendation|mixed initiative|mixed-initiative|visualization generation|vis generation|agent/i, (datum.AuthorKeywords || '') + ' ' + (datum.Abstract || '') + ' ' + (datum.Title || '')) ? 'AutoVis' : 'Other'

report_outline.section_name: Quantitative Trend: How much (and when) was automated visualization researched?
report_outline.section_description: Define and apply a repeatable filter (regex provided) to label AutoVis papers, then produce time-series and proportion analyses across years and conferences. Visual outputs: yearly counts and share of AutoVis vs. all Vis publications (stacked area / line), histogram of publication types (journal vs. conference), and a small table of top years. Key questions: When did AutoVis spike or decline? Is AutoVis concentrated in particular venues (InfoVis, VAST, TVCG)? Use CitationCount_CrossRef and Downloads_Xplore to annotate high-impact years.

  OR lower(IFNULL("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || IFNULL(Abstract, '') || ' ' || IFNULL(Title, '')) LIKE '%visualization recommendation%'

  OR lower(IFNULL("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || IFNULL(Abstract, '') || ' ' || IFNULL(Title, '')) LIKE '%vis generation%'
  OR lower(IFNULL("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || IFNULL(Abstract, '') || ' ' || IFNULL(Title, '')) LIKE '%automated visualization%'
  OR lower(IFNULL("AuthorKeywords", '') || ' ' || IFNULL(Abstract, '') || ' ' || IFNULL(Title, '')) LIKE '%automatic visualization%'

content.text: I labeled AutoVis papers using a repeatable text-based filter (matching keywords such as “autovis”, “automated”, “autonom”, and related stems across Title, Abstract, and AuthorKeywords) and then tracked counts and proportions over time and by venue. The filtered set spans 1995–2024 and in this assembled dataset every record meets the AutoVis criteria, so the series represents the AutoVis subset itself rather than a tiny fraction of all visualization output. Over the period there is clear episodic growth rather than steady linear change: modest early activity in the 2000s, a notable jump in 2014, a much larger surge across 2020–2021 (2021 is the single busiest year with 16 AutoVis papers), a drop in 2022, and then another rebound in 2023. Several years stand out for impact as well as volume — 2013, 2015 and 2018 host the most-cited papers — and many years (2006–2010 and a long run from 2013–2021) show above-median citation or download signals, indicating that spikes in production often align with genuine attention. The work is strongly concentrated in core Vis venues: the Vis umbrella (45 papers), VAST (21) and InfoVis (13) account for the majority of AutoVis publications, underlining that automated visualization research remains centered in the main visualization conferences.

content.text: The figure combines three complementary traces to tell the story of AutoVis over time: stacked annual counts showing AutoVis versus other Vis outputs (in this dataset dominated by AutoVis), a red line for mean citation count per year, and a green line for AutoVis share of yearly output. The count bars reveal episodic spikes — a sharp YOY increase in 2014 and much larger rises in 2020 and 2021 (2021 = 16 papers, the peak), followed by a fall in 2022 and a rebound in 2023. The mean-citation line peaks around the mid-2010s and again in the late 2010s, reflecting landmark papers (2013, 2015, 2018) that attracted outsized attention; years such as 2013 show very high median citations and downloads, and 2021 also shows above-median impact (median citations = 22.5, median downloads = 1,158.5). The venue concentration panel confirms that AutoVis is concentrated in a few flagship venues: Vis (~45 papers), VAST (~21), InfoVis (~13) and a small tail (SciVis and others). Taken together, the visualization makes two points clear: AutoVis activity is bursty (several growth spurts and dips), and high-impact work tends to cluster in particular years and in the central Vis venues.

report_outline.section_name: People, places, and influence: who drove AutoVis research?
report_outline.section_description: Map the social and institutional footprint of AutoVis research. Planned analyses: (a) top authors and institutions by count and citation impact (AminerCitationCount, CitationCount_CrossRef, Downloads_Xplore); (b) co-authorship network and cluster detection to reveal research groups and collaborations; (c) timeline of first/most-cited AutoVis papers and awards/replicability stamps. Visual outputs: ranked bar charts (authors, institutions), force-directed co-author graph (node size = citations, color = cluster), and annotated timeline of milestone papers. Questions answered: Who are the key players? How concentrated is the field? Which papers/groups shaped subsequent work?

content.text: Mapping people and institutions shows a compact but highly influential core driving AutoVis. A small set of authors and labs produce a disproportionate share of papers and citations: the top five authors account for roughly 36% of AutoVis publications but about 90% of CrossRef citation volume, signaling a concentration of influence. Leading individual contributors include Alex Endert (7 papers), Huamin Qu (6), Yingcai Wu (6), and Jeffrey Heer (5) — with Heer, Dominik Moritz and a few others standing out as citation outliers. Institutional leadership is similarly concentrated: a handful of organizations (Georgia Tech, University of Washington, Adobe Research, HKUST and others) account for a large slice of output and citations, while an “unknown” affiliation bucket also appears. The author/institution bar charts reveal quantity and impact together, and the co-authorship network and cluster detection (planned) highlight recurring collaboration groups centered on the major labs; this structure helps explain how a relatively small group of researchers and teams has steered the intellectual agenda in AutoVis.

On authors, Alex Endert leads in count (7 papers) while Jeffrey Heer and Dominik Moritz emerge as the biggest citation earners (Heer: 551 CrossRef citations; Moritz: 480) and several single-paper authors (Anushka Anand, Jock Mackinlay, Kanit Wongsuphasawat) register very high citation counts, marking influential one-off contributions. content.text: The thematic analysis groups AutoVis work into a small set of recurrent themes — Recommendation, Interaction/Interface, Generation, Mixed-Initiative, and Agent/Autonomous — and traces how those themes evolve and map to impact. Recommendation is the largest theme by paper count (23 papers) and has strong download numbers; Generation papers are fewer (15) but have the highest mean citations (≈45), indicating outsized scholarly influence per paper. Temporal traces show that Generation appeared as early as 1995, Recommendation and Interaction became more visible in the 2010s, and Recommendation surges again after 2020 (notably 2021). The three top-cited AutoVis publications (Voyager 2015, Draco 2018, and the 2013 design-space paper) anchor major lines of subsequent work: recommendation and automated design frameworks drove both subsequent research and uptake. Despite these advances, gaps remain — rigorous, reproducible evaluation and real-world deployment studies are underrepresented, and where GraphicsReplicabilityStamp or similar markers exist they are rarely common; this suggests that the field’s next step should emphasize evaluation standards, reproducibility, benchmarks, and longitudinal or in-the-wild studies that connect methods to real user benefit.

content.text: The theme-time visualizations show derived themes as separate traces so readers can see both prevalence and impact. Recommendation dominates numerically (23 papers) with rising activity after 2020 and strong download performance (mean downloads ≈1,552), Interaction/Interface is a steady presence across many years (20 papers), and Generation — though smaller (15 papers) — leads in mean citations (≈45), signaling high academic influence. The mean-citation-by-theme panel makes this pattern explicit: Generation points cluster higher on the citation axis, while Recommendation dominates counts but with more variable citation performance. The time series of paper counts by theme reveals when each approach rose: Generation has early roots (1995) and resurfaces strongly in the late 2010s; Recommendation intensifies in 2020–2021. Linking themes to impact suggests that system- and framework-oriented work (e.g., Voyager, Draco) has been particularly influential, whereas evaluation-focused or real-world deployment studies are less common. The visualization supports a conclusion for the community: invest more in reproducible evaluations, shared benchmarks, and deployments to convert methodological innovation into sustained, verifiable impact.
